body:
Comment 1: 
> I can work around this (I /really/ hate lines longer than 80 characters)
> by splitting in the middle of the parameter or argument list.
> (the parser doesn't mind because of the ()).

The parser has no idea; it's not the ( ).
It's that you can always break a line after ( or , without introducing a semicolon.
Or you could use a shorter function name.

This is a known consequence of the semicolon rules,
and I admit it's a bothersome one.  On the other hand,
you get the nice property that after reading 

   func f()

on a line by itself any tool (say, an interactive interpreter)
knows the function declaration is over and doesn't need
to keep reading.

Changing the rules would mean making them more
complicated.  I don't see this happening any time soon,
but it's still an experiment.
